articles.author: Dimitri 'phaazon' Sabadie <dimitri.sabadie@gmail.com>
articles.description:
Neovim Core updates
Updates of Neovim itself, which are available on Neovim nightly.
Important: some updates might be missing from this week content. If you want to be sure to always keep up to
date with what’s going on in Neovim Core, you are strongly advised to have a look to these places:
@neovim on Twitter, which tweets the most recent news about the editor.
:h news.txt will deliver you with the last news inside Neovim directly.
Various PRs on GitHub.
Neovim Plugin Community updates
Neovim is full of active plugins. This section is about the community and what is going on.
New plugins

      
    
    easyread.nvim
  


easyread.nvim brings bionic-like reading to Neovim. With features like saccades and custom highlighting, you can 
tailor your reading experience just how you like.
Redd…
articles.title: 20 Mar 2023

articles.description:
Neovim Core updates
Updates of Neovim itself, which are available on Neovim nightly.
Important: if you are a plugin author, you are strongly advised to follow the
#14090 breaking changes on master GitHub thread, as it contains
important breaking changes information.
Breaking changes are now tracked in :help news

Breaking changes are now tracked in :help news
You can subscribe via…

RSS: http://github.com/neovim/neovim/commits/master/runtime/doc/news.txt.atom
Third-party service: enter https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/runtime/doc/news.txt at https://app.github-file-watcher.com/
Where possible, breaking changes are also flagged with vim.deprecate()
Neovim Plugin Community updates
Neovim is full of active plugins. This section is about the community and what is going on.
New plug…

Neovim Core updates
Updates of Neovim itself, which are available on Neovim nightly.
Important: if you are a plugin author, you are strongly advised to follow the
#14090 breaking changes on master GitHub thread, as it contains
important breaking changes information.
Neovim Plugin Community updates
Neovim is full of active plugins. This section is about the community and what is going on.
New plugins

      
    
    mini.bracketed
  


  

A mini.bracketed module of mini.nvim implements functionality and mappings
to go forward/backward with square brackets. This is a Lua evolution of
tpope/vim-unimpaired with much more targets:

TargetMappings

Buffer[B [b ]b ]B
Comment block[C [c ]c ]C
Conflict marker[X [x ]x ]X
Diagnostic[D [d ]d ]D
File on disk[F [f ]f ]F
Indent change[I [i ]i ]I
Jump f…
articles.title: 27 Feb 2023

sources.title: Dan Abramov's Overreacted Blog RSS Feed

articles.description:
We've achieved our goals already with this series: we have a web service written in Rust, built into a Docker image with nix, with a nice dev shell, that we can deploy to fly.io.

But there's always room for improvement, and so I wanted to talk about a few things we didn't bother doing in the previous chapters.

Making clash-geoip available in the dev shell
articles.title: Extra credit

articles.description:
There it is. The final instalment.

Over the course of this series, we've built a very useful Rust web service that shows us colored ASCII art cats, and we've packaged it with docker, and deployed it to https://fly.io.
articles.title: Generating a docker image with nix

articles.description:
In the previous chapter, we've made a nix "dev shell" that contained the fly.io command-line utility, "flyctl".

That said, that's not how I want us to define a dev shell.
articles.title: Making a dev shell with nix flakes

articles.description:
Remember the snapshot we made allll the way back in Part 1? Now's the time to use it.

Well, make sure you've committed and pushed all your changes, but when you're ready, let's go back in time to before we installed anything catscii-specific in our VM.
articles.title: Learning Nix from the bottom up

articles.description:
I sold you on some additional functionality for catscii last chapter, and we got caught up in private registry / docker shenanigans, so, now, let's resume web development as promised.

Adding geolocation
articles.title: Doing geo-location and keeping analytics
Using the Shipyard private crate registry with Docker

articles.description:
Disclosure: Because I used to work for fly.io, I still benefit from an employee discount at the time of this writing: I don't have to pay for anything deployed there for now.

fly.io is still sponsoring me for developing hring, but this isn't a sponsored post. It's just a good fit for what we're doing here, with a generous free tier.
articles.title: Deploying catscii to fly.io

articles.description:
Now that our service is production-ready, it's time to deploy it somewhere.

There's a lot of ways to approach this: what we are going to do, though, is build a docker image. Or, I should say, an OCI image.
articles.title: Writing a Dockerfile for catscii

articles.description:
Our catscii program does everything we want it to do, except that it's a command-line application rather than a web server. Let's fix that.

Enter axum
articles.title: Serving ASCII cats over HTTP

articles.description:
Now that our development environment is all set up, let's make something useful!

Creating the catscii crate
articles.title: Printing ASCII cats to the terminal

articles.description:
With the previous part's VM still running, let's try connecting to our machine over SSH.

Network addresses, loopback and IP nets
articles.title: Developing over SSH

articles.description:
The first step to using Nix to build Rust is to do so without Nix, so that when we finally do, we can feel the difference.

There's many ways to go about this: everyone has their favorite code editor, base Linux distribution (there's even a NixOS distribution, which I won't cover). Some folks like to develop on macOS first, and then build for Linux.
articles.title: Setting up a local Ubuntu Server VM

articles.author: craighafer
articles.description:
Date#commercial is what you're looking for! It will create a Date object for you based on the year,week,  and day that you give it.
require 'date'

# Wednesday (3) of week 1 of year 2023
Date.commercial(2023, 1, 3)
Date.commercial(Date.current.year, Date.current.cweek, 5)
Rails TimeHelpers to travel to that specific date you need:
next_friday = Date.commercial(Date.current.year, Date.current.cweek + 1, 5)

travel_to next_friday do
  # Friday specific code
end
articles.title: Create a Date object for a specific day - #ruby

articles.title: Phone and Email links in Markdown - #html-css

articles.author: andrewvogel
articles.description:
alert and notice; you can use them like this in your controller: 
redirect_to users_path, notice: "User created successfully"
# - or -
render :new, alert: "An error prevented the user from being saved"
flash[:success] = "User created successfully"
redirect_to users_path
add_flash_type. You can use this an a controller (re: ApplicationController) to enable new flash message types. This will allow you to do the one liners in render and redirect calls: 
class ApplicationController < ActionController::Base
  add_flash_type :my_flash_type
end

# ...

redirect_to users_path, my_flash_type: "User created successfully"
# - or -
render :new, my_flash_type: "An error prevented the user from being saved"
<%= my_flash_type %>
https://api.rubyonrails.org/classes/ActionController/Flash/ClassMethods.html
articles.title: Custom Flash Messages in Rails - #rails

articles.author: andrewvogel
articles.description:
apply_changes/1 function to apply that changeset and receive schema with which you can perform operations. It's worth noting that the data is not validated when changes are applied, so care needs to be taken to ensure validity before an attempt to save that record.
iex> lead_schema = Lead.changeset(%{name: "Andrew", email: "Andrew.Vogel@hashrocket.com"})
                   |> apply_changes() 
%Lead{name: "Andrew", email: "Andrew.Vogel@hashrocket.com"}

iex> lead_schema |> downcase_email() |> do_some_other_processing()
https://hexdocs.pm/ecto/Ecto.Changeset.html#apply_changes/1
articles.title: Convert Changeset Into Schema With `apply_changes` - #elixir
